div.p:
Good afternoon Parents and Guardians,
I would like to provide a very brief update regarding the extension of our school closure. As noted this afternoon by the Governor, the school closure period has been extended to May 20, 2020. I understand the concerns everyone has regarding this decision and whether or not we will reopen again this year, but I believe the Governor and advisors remain hopeful that we may be able to resume in-school learning prior to the end of school year.
Upon our return from school vacation on April 20th, I will be updating families regarding the way in which grading will occur for the final marking quarter. This has been raised as a concern of many students and families, and we will be providing an update regarding the ways in which student learning will be assessed throughout the closure period.
I appreciate your continued support throughout this endeavor, and I wish everyone health and happiness during our vacation week.
Sincerely,
Timothy M. Van Tasel

br.br:
The Board of Education voted to maintain our April vacation as scheduled on the 2019-2020 school calendar. As a result, distance learning will be discontinued for the period of April 10 through April 17, 2020. We will recommence our distance learning activities on April 20, 2020.
Please note that an additional correspondence may be sent as early as tomorrow evening regarding the extension of our school closure beyond April 20th.
Sincerely,
Timothy M. Van Tasel, Superintendent

div.p:
I am very hopeful that this update finds all of our families and your loved ones in good health during this very difficult time. It has been a little over a week since my last correspondence, which was due in part to the many other communications you have been receiving from the schools, our various district level departments, as well as, updates you have received from the Town. In addition, I have waited in hopes of having further information regarding whether or not our schools would reopen again this year. While we are all hopeful that we will once again fill our hallways with our students and staff, the decision of when, and if, remains in question at this point.
As noted by Governor Lamont in Friday’s news conference, it is likely that our closure will be well beyond our initial extension of April 20th. In my weekly conference call with our Commissioner of Education, Dr. Miguel Cordona, it was stated that the Department of Education would like to provide notice to families on or before April 10th. At this point, we have to anticipate that an extension is likely due to the infection trend projections that have been shared by the Connecticut Department of Public Health. With the Hartford County peak ranging between May 10th to May 24th, the peak infection trends indicate that our school closure period will be for an indefinite period of time. There are many factors that could change this scenario, which makes it important that we follow this closely in the days and weeks ahead.
In terms of our distance learning, we will continue to follow an incremental approach to assist our students and parents with the transition to online instruction. The abilities of our students, the availability of working parents, and determining the most effective way to provide interactive lessons are the current challenges we will need to overcome in the days and weeks ahead. Although there are some common themes in the feedback we have received from our distance learning surveys, each student and family situation is unique and no single solution is the right answer. We understand the incredible difficulty parents are experiencing with juggling work, family, and now the role of teacher – and we want to support you in any way possible. The district has prepared a tremendous amount of resources that students and parents can access on our district website under our special Continuity of Learning webpage.
As I will continue to state, distance learning is no replacement for direct instruction and we look forward to the day our students will return to their classrooms. We have already begun planning for their transitions back to school, assessing what additional supports will be needed to make up for the lost instructional time, and reviewing the scope and sequence of our units of study to compensate for learning gaps. We recognize that it is highly likely that our students will be returning to school with varying degrees of content understanding, and we will adjust our instruction to ensure that all students are able to make up for areas that may need further teaching. In the meantime, we ask that our students and parents do their best to utilize the instructional plans that have been developed, as well as, make use of the interactive opportunities that teachers will be providing. Our continuity of learning will inevitably improve with each week, and I thank our students, parents, teachers, and administrators for the incredible efforts being made during this time of tremendous uncertainty.
In terms of technology, our district continues to make every effort to provide a timely response to Chromebook issues. We have utilized our entire inventory to stretch out our coverage to the primary grades; however, we recognize that additional Chromebooks will be needed if we begin to see replacement needs due to issues with the devices. The district will be purchasing additional Chromebooks in the weeks ahead, but as of right now most of the companies have items on backorder due to the sharp increase in demand. If your child is having an issue with their device, please utilize our SchoolDude management system for technology support. The link for technology support can be found on our district website under Student Device Tech Support.
Lastly, the Board of Education (BOE) will be presenting their FY21 Budget proposal to the Board of Finance (BOF) this evening at 7:00 pm through a Zoom video conference. The BOE will provide the rationale to its proposed 2.12% increase and answer any corresponding questions. Information on how to attend/listen this meeting can be located on the April 6, 2020 BOE Meeting Agenda. I will provide follow-up information to our parent community regarding the town’s budget deliberation process in the weeks ahead.
Once again, I appreciate your patience and understanding as it relates to our school closure and the current health crisis we are currently in. If you have any questions, concerns, or suggestions, please do not hesitate to reach out to me.
Sincerely,
Timothy M. Van Tasel

At the Governor’s direction, school districts will remain closed through April 20, 2020. It is important to note that this is not a firm date for the reopening of schools. If the community spread of the virus intensifies over the next several weeks, it is possible that our closure will be extended further. The Governor’s Office, Connecticut State Department of Education, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and our local health department will be providing further guidance about reopening schools when it is appropriate to do so. At this point, we remain very hopeful that communities around the state will follow the guidance given by our health experts to minimize the spread of COVID-19 and protect the health and welfare of residents.

div.p: The decision to change school schedules is made after careful review of information collected from the local Police, Highway, transportation company, and the School Maintenance Departments. Road conditions, sidewalk status, precipitation, temperatures and forecasts are all considered when making a determination to delay or close school. In some circumstances, a delay may be upgraded to a school closing. Information related to delayed openings and school closures is also broadcasted on the television and radio stations below, typically by 5:30 a.m. As always, the safety of our children is the priority factor in all decision making.

The District uses an electronic communication system called SchoolMessenger to manage notifications. The system is used to make phone calls, and send emails and texts, about school closings/delays, emergencies, alerts, and general notifications.
